headline: Webchat: how to write your personal statement
text: When Ucas applications start flooding in to universities, admissions tutors will be faced with thousands of personal statements. How can you make yours stand out? In just 47 lines you need to show that you're academically able, enthusiastic and committed to your field. How can you overcome writer's block and write the perfect first sentence? What are the phrases that make admissions tutors yawn? And, what should you do if you're applying to more than one subject? From 1-2pm on Tuesday we'll be joined by admissions tutors and undergraduate recruitment officers from Manchester, Swansea and Leeds University will be here to answer your queries. You can put your question to our experts now by posting them in the comment section below or by emailing students@theguardian.com. The panel Rebecca Lee is an undergraduate recruitment and widening participation officer at Manchester University. Dr Abigail Harrison-Moore was an admissions tutor for seven years at the School of Fine Art, History of Art and Cultural Studies, University of Leeds, where she is now head of school. Barry Clark is student recruitment manager at Swansea University. He has 10 years experience advising sixth formers and college students as a careers adviser.Hannah Morton-Hedges works as a careers adviser in schools and universities.
